questions.text: Which of the following best defines "Market Demand"?
options: The quantity a single household is willing to buy at a specific price.
The total quantity of all goods produced by firms in an economy.
The desire of consumers to purchase goods regardless of their ability to pay.
The total quantity of a specific commodity that all consumers in a market are willing and able to purchase at a given price over a specific time period.

questions.text: If a fall in the price of Good Y causes a decrease in the demand for Good X, how are these two commodities related?
options: They are complementary goods
They are substitute goods
They are luxury goods
They are Giffen goods

questions.text: According to the principle of "Income of the Consumer," a good is classified as "Inferior" when:
options: Its demand remains unchanged as income rises
Its demand increases proportionally with a rise in income
It is an inexpensive foodstuff like salt
Its demand falls as consumer income rises beyond a certain level

questions.text: [Answer: A] Which of the following describes the relationship between a good and its "Complement" on a graph? A
options: The curve slopes downward, showing that a fall in the price of the complement increases demand for the good.
The curve slopes upward, showing that a fall in the price of the complement decreases demand for the good.
The curve is vertical, showing no relationship between the two.
The curve is horizontal, showing demand is perfectly elastic.
Quantity demanded will rise indefinitely.
Quantity demanded will remain completely or largely unaffected.
Quantity demanded will fall to zero.
The consumer will switch to a more expensive substitute.

questions.text: In economics, the terms "expansion" and "contraction" of demand are used to describe changes in quantity demanded specifically caused by:
options: Changes in the price of the commodity itself
Changes in the consumer's level of income
Changes in tastes and fashion
Changes in the prices of substitute goods

questions.text: A "contraction" in demand is graphically represented by:
options: A rightward shift of the entire demand curve
An upward movement along a given demand curv
A downward movement along a given demand curve
A leftward shift of the entire demand curve

questions.text: According to the text, expansion and contraction of demand occur only when which of the following remains constant?
options: Tastes and preferences
Household income
Prices of related goods
All of the above (Ceteris Paribus)

questions.text: If the price of a product decreases from $P$ to $P_1$, resulting in a movement from a higher point to a lower point on the same demand curve, this is known as:
options: A decrease in demand
An increase in demand
An expansion in demand
A shift in demand

questions.text: An increase in the minimum wage leads to higher consumer incomes. Graphically, how would this affect the demand for a normal good like clothes?
options: An upward movement along the existing demand curve.
A downward movement along the existing demand curve.
A leftward shift of the entire demand curve.
A rightward shift of the entire demand curve.

questions.text: Which of the following specifically causes a "change in demand" (a shift of the curve) rather than a "change in quantity demanded"?
options: A reduction in the market price of the good.
A change in consumer tastes and preferences.
An increase in the cost of production.
An improvement in manufacturing technology.

questions.text: [Answer: D] The term "ceteris paribus" in the context of the demand function Qd = a - bP implies that:
options: Price and income are changing simultaneously
The demand curve is shifting to the right
The supply of the good is perfectly elastic
All factors other than the price of the commodity remain constant.

questions.text: [Answer: B] Consider a market demand function represented by the equation Qd = 200 - 4P + 0.5Y, where Qd is the quantity demanded, P is the price, and Y is the household income. If the current price is $20 and the average household income is $400, what is the quantity demanded?
options: 220 units
320 units
120 units
400 units

questions.text: A consumer's demand function for a specific good is Qd = 150 - 10P. If the market price increases from $5 to $8, what is the resulting change in the quantity demanded?
options: An expansion of 30 units
An expansion of 100 units
A contraction of 80 units
A contraction of 30 units
